utterances: And, by the way, because of the extent of the civil suit and judgment against O.J.
Simpson - remember, it's $33.5 million, which not a nickel has been paid.
As a result of that, the Goldmans are saying, look, if it indeed is in fact the case, that these items that O.J.
says are his, if they are his, we want them too, and we're going to sell them.
Thanks very much for being with us.
Appreciate your time today.
Earl Ofari Hutchinson is the author of ""Beyond O.J.: Race, Sex and Class Lessons for America."" He was a media and trial commentator during both O.J.
Simpson trials.
He joined us today by phone from Los Angeles.
The Federal Reserve has cut a key interest rate for the first time in four years.
The half point cut for the federal funds rate, the interest that banks charge each other, is double what many economists predicted.
Stay tuned for further coverage of that later today on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
The weekend fire at a warehouse party in Oakland, Calif., has claimed more than 30 lives, and that's just the count up to now.
Local officials say they don't know how many more bodies they'll find as the recovery effort enters its third day.
NPR's Richard Gonzales reports.
To say there is profound grief in Oakland is to do little justice to the depth of emotions as people leave flowers and candles and wait to learn whether a friend was among the victims.
A young woman who identifies herself only as Anna stands sobbing next to the area cordoned off by the police.
She says her friend Conrad is missing, and she only knows that he attended a party in this neighborhood Friday night.
He didn't say that he was safe.
And I have no clue where he is, but it's very likely that he was in there.
So, I mean, just in general, I want to be here to, like, show my support.
The fire began about 11:30 Friday night in a two-story warehouse turned artist enclave.
Officials say the first floor was a labyrinth of small living spaces with hanging rugs and tapestries and old wooden furniture.
Upstairs, Friday, there was a party with live music.
Between the floors was a makeshift staircase made of wooden pallets - perfect fuel for a fire, say experts.
The graffiti-marked building was known as the Ghost Ship.
It's kind of a scary-looking place.
I wouldn't go in there.
I wouldn't walk in front either.
Insurance salesman Fernando Valenzuela said neighbors had been complaining about the building for years.
Just the blight.
This - you know, I love this place.
I grew up here.
To see the graffiti and the debris and garbage in the streets, it's just disconcerting, you know?
It was a difficult negotiation.
We had to get the reparation issue right.
We said it doesn't solve it.
It doesn't give it, it doesn't solve it.
And that was a key part of a negotiation that was touchy.
But first, we go to Oregon, where Democratic Governor Ted Kulongoski is expected to sign a bill this week to grant domestic partnerships to gays and lesbians.
That would be a victory for Kelly Burke and Dolores Doyle.
They're a lesbian couple living in Portland.
We've been following their story on DAY TO DAY.
Here's Kelly.
This is not about politics for me.
It's deeply personal.
It's about my life, Dolores' life, the lives of our kids and the many families like ours.
Recently, Colin Fogarty of Oregon Public Broadcasting spent some time with the couple.
The scene in Kelly Burke's living room is right out of a Norman Rockwell painting.
(Soundbite of a child crying)
She's a stay-at-home mom holding her toddler, watching her spouse mow the lawn outside.
(Soundbite of lawn mower)
The difference is that her spouse mowing the lawn is a woman, Dolores Doyle.
You know, we're hardly a perfect lawn people, so just got to cut the weeds down.
Inside, the children called Doyle mama, and Burke is designated as mommy.
The kids know it better than we do.
We, you know, say it backwards all the time.
But they are very clear who is mama and who is mommy.
Burke and Doyle say since last we talked, their lives have been anything but normal.
They have two children now and Doyle is recovering from breast cancer.
(Unintelligible) have been very surprised what a long haul it was.
So far so good, you know.
It's sort of the long-term prognosis that...
You never know it's going to happen.
The illness gave Burke and Doyle a new urgency to get their relationship legally recognized.
Most of the doctors and nurses they saw had no problem that they're lesbians.
But the issue hit them like a brick when Doyle's breathing became labored and Burke called a cancer nurse for advice.
I said, this is her partner, Kelly.
And before I got any further, you know, I started to detail what was going on, I was cut off and she said I'm sorry ma'am, I need to speak with Dolores.
So at that point I just got Dolores, kind of woke her up, gave her the phone.
Dolores just said, this is Dolores, I need you to talk to Kelly and handed the phone back.
The incident was a reminder of a debate that's been ranging in Oregon for the better part of two decades.
In the 1990s, Oregonians voted on a series of controversial anti-gay rights ballot measures.
Then in 2004, county officials in Portland ignited a political and legal firestorm when they granted marriage licenses to 3,000 gay couples.
Burke and Doyle were among the first.
But within a year a judge declared the marriage license as null and void and Oregon voters banned gay marriage altogether.
The vote pushed gay rights advocates like Burke and Doyle to lobby the legislature for civil unions or domestic partnerships.
After all the ups and downs, they don't care what it's called.
You know, we've been committed.
We've been domesticated.
If it was to become civil unions, we'd be civilized.
But, you know, it's like our...
You know, we've been married.
We've been annulled.
We've done it all.
You know, its just words.
The real key is having the rights and the protections.
So with the ban on gay marriage remaining in effect, Burke and Doyle are hoping Oregonians will see domestic partnerships as a compromise they can live with.
We have other things we have to think about, you know.
Our son is starting school.
You know, our daughter is one.
Yeah.
We have things we got to take care of and plan for - I think creating a legitimate definition of our relationship is really important.
Boy, it has been quite the journey.
I do think that Oregon has been having this conversation for a very long time.
This conversation, Oregon's done with it.
It's time.
It's now, and people are done worrying about gays and lesbians.
And I do think that we're ready.
But much of the country might not be.
Ten states, plus the District of Columbia, now have some form of official recognition of gay relationships.
But those unions are not generally recognized in other states or by the federal government.
For NPR News.
I'm Collin Fogarty in Portland.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Luke Burbank.
Tomorrow night, as he gives his State of the Union Address, President Bush will be in uncharted waters.
He'll be addressing a Democratically-controlled Congress for the first time.
And another first, he's expected to make health care a major theme of the speech, specifically a new plan to provide health coverage for the uninsured.
Here with us is NPR's health policy correspondent Julie Rovner.
Hi, Julie.
Hi, Luke.
So what is the status right now with health care in the U.S.? How many people have and how many people don't?
Well, there's about 47 million people who don't have insurance.
And the president has kind of mentioned this on and off, but, as you say, he's going to make it a centerpiece, I think, of this speech.
So what exactly is the president proposing?
I understand that he's going to talk about taxing people's health care as a form of income if you have it provided by your company.
That's right.
Now, right now, most of people who get their insurance through their jobs don't pay taxes on it.
And people who buy their own insurance don't get a deduction for buying that insurance.

So basically, you could have a new tax deduction for people who buy insurance on their own, and it would be paid for by people who are currently getting insurance and not paying taxes on that insurance.
And so, of course, you've got a lot of folks lining up on the other side of the president on this saying, look, this is basically robbing Peter to pay Paul.
You're taking money away from people who have a health insurance to try to fund it over on the other side.
Not everyone is a fan of this, I guess.
Well, yeah.
This is an amazing political proposal and that it unites business and labor in opposition to it.
